Award.AwardTitle: Social interactions and the maintenance of genetic polymorphism
Award.AbstractNarration:
For decades biologists have struggled to determine whether and when individual behavior is influenced more by "nature" (genes) or "nurture" (social environment). While both are known to matter, emerging research suggests that "nature" and "nurture" are actually complex phenomena that are frequently difficult to disentangle. This question becomes even more complex when individuals are part of a social group. Therefore the goal of this project is to understand how social groups behave toward individuals with different sets of genes and how individuals with different genes might respond differently to the same social cues. One way to make this problem more tractable is to use tightly controlled experiments with an animal species in which specific behavioral differences are regulated by a single gene. The proposed research will use two genetically determined color forms of male mosquitofish that differ in the amount of aggression they display toward other members of their group. The experiments will determine how group composition affects the behavior of juvenile and adult fish. The studies will answer critical questions of the interaction between individuals and groups, such as how does living in a "high aggression" group affect the health and behavior of a juvenile fish, and does any effect of "high" vs. "low" aggression depend on the juvenile's own genetic makeup or is it regulated primarily by the social environment?

Upon publication data will be stored and available on DRYAD (datadryad.org. Results of these experiments will be broadly useful in understanding the factors that influence aggression and other social behavior in animals, including humans. In addition, the project will stimulate teaching and learning, increase research opportunities for students from underrepresented groups, and contribute to public understanding of science. The project will support the training of one female Ph.D. student, and will involve undergraduates from under-represented groups. The investigators will also develop a workshop on animal social behavior and genetics for Florida secondary school teachers as part of a funded "BioScopes" project. The workshop will consist of lectures and "hands-on" activities that can be adapted to the teachers' classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We used eastern mosquitofish as a model system to understand the interplay between genetic diversity, individual behavior, and social interactions. We measured differences between genetically-determined color types in behavior, growth, and physiology (direct genetic effects), and whether these differences affected social partners (‘indirect” or “social genetic effects’). Both direct and indirect genetic effects can profoundly affect individual health and performance, population growth patterns, and interactions between species. Our results indicate that direct and indirect genetic effects influence behavior, growth, and stress response and that these effects likely contribute to the maintenance of genetic diversity. However, the pervasive effects of (genetic) variation in the social environment at early stages of development suggest that even apparently innate differences could arise from these indirect social effects.

Intellectual Merit

We found that males of genetically different color types (‘silver’ and ‘melanic’) experienced different social environments. Melanic males had more social partners, and especially more female social partners. These initial results suggest that both direct and social genetic effects can play a role in the expression and evolution of social behavior in this species. These results were published in Kraft et al. 2016 Ethology 122: 869-880.

We also found that both genetic type and the genetic composition of the social environment influenced social development. Melanic and silver fish did not differ in aggression, but they did differ in mating behavior and in the aggressive behavior they received from social partners. These results imply that even apparently innate (direct genetic) differences in behavior might arise as indirect effects of differences in the experienced social environment (Kraft, et al. 2018. Behavioral Ecology 29: 289-300). We also measured feeding behavior and body condition in this experiment, and found that social genetic effects influenced both traits. Feeding rates were lower for both silver and melanic fish when the social environment contained more melanic males. However, males of both types had better body condition when they were reared in an environment in which their own type was rare. This pattern suggests that rarity itself is advantageous, a type of selection that can actively maintain genetic diversity within populations (Culumber et al. 2018, Evolution 72:1146-1154). 

As part of a Research Experience for Undergraduates, we evaluated a recently-proposed hypothesis that male harassment imposes selection for larger female brains.  Using fish from a natural population, we found that large female body size, but not brain size, correlated with a female’s ability to avoid harassment. Melanic males directed more attention toward females (consistent with earlier results), and females directed more attention to males that directed more attention to them. The association between female and male attention highlights an intriguing possibility that females may exert more control over male mating behavior than previously acknowledged in this species. Our results indicate that female brain size may have little impact on reducing male sexual coercion in mosquitofish (Culumber, et al. 2020. Animal Behaviour 160: 15-24).

Finally, we investigated effects of natural predators (bass) on behavior and stress-hormone levels. Melanic males were more active than silver males, and their behavior changed more in the presence of predators than did silver males. All males decreased activity in the presence of predators, but the decline was greater in melanic males. Melanic males had higher cortisol levels than silver males in the absence of predators, but melanic male cortisol levels were only half as high in the absence of predators. In contrast, cortisol concentrations of silver males were slightly higher in the predator treatment than in controls, indicating that melanic and silver males modulate stress response differently. Because hormones that regulate melanin concentration also influence cortisol release, these physiological differences might be genetically linked to the color differences. 

 Broader Impacts 

The research has substantial broader impact because of its implication that genetic differences can influence the behavior received by an individual, thereby confounding attempts to attribute differences in behavior to innate (genetic) causes. Other broader impacts involved meaningful research experiences for undergraduates and scholarship related to STEM Education. All the papers cited above had undergraduate co-authors who participated in design, implementation, and data analysis, thereby gaining working knowledge of the scientific enterprise. Authorship on peer-reviewed papers will enhance career prospects for these students (all female) in industry or in admission to postgraduate programs. 

Two female graduate students (one African American) supported on the project earned PhDs (B. Kraft, E. Humphrey). One of these students (Humphrey) also engaged in pedagogical research, publishing two papers focused on STEM education (Callis-Duehl et al. 2017, Journal of Science Education and Technology 27: 86-98; Humphrey et al. 2020. The American Biology Teacher 82:53-57). Humphrey also produced a “newborn dissertation photoshoot” that was featured on Good Morning America, and many other popular outlets, and was a viral sensation on Facebook. This publicity drew considerable attention to an African American woman celebrating completion of a STEM PhD.
